label.name_singular: Physical rights are retained by (your institution name here). Copyright is retained in accordance with U.S. Copyright laws.
label.name_plural: Physical rights are retained by (your institution name here). Copyright is retained in accordance with U.S. Copyright laws.

label.name_singular: Les droits sont réservés par (le nom de votre institution). Droits de reproduction réservés en accord avec les lois sur le Copyright des Etats-Unis.
label.name_plural: Les droits sont réservés par (le nom de votre institution). Droits de reproduction réservés en accord avec les lois sur le Copyright des Etats-Unis.

label.description: Attribution---This licence lets others distribute, remix, adapt, and build upon your work, even commercially, as long as they credit you for the original creation. This is the most accommodating of licences offered. Recommended for maximum dissemination and use of licenced materials.

Attribution-ShareAlike---This licence lets others remix, adapt, and build upon your work even for commercial purposes, as long as they credit you and licence their new creations under the identical terms. This licence is often compared to “copyleft” free and open source software licences. All new works based on yours will carry the same licence, so any derivatives will also allow commercial use. This is the licence used by Wikipedia, and is recommended for materials that would benefit from incorporating content from Wikipedia and similarly licenced projects.
Attribution-NoDerivs---This licence lets others reuse the work for any purpose, including commercially; however, it cannot be shared with others in adapted form, and credit must be provided to you.

Attribution-NonCommercial-ShareAlike---This licence lets others remix, adapt, and build upon your work non-commercially, as long as they credit you and licence their new creations under the identical terms.

Attribution-NonCommercial-NoDerivs---This licence is the most restrictive of our six main licences, only allowing others to download your works and share them with others as long as they credit you, but they can’t change them in any way or use them commercially.

Public Domain--- is a public dedication tool, which allows creators to give up their copyright and put their works into the worldwide public domain. CC0 allows reusers to distribute, remix, adapt, and build upon the material in any medium or format, with no conditions.

Highly sensitive – refers to resource that cannot be viewed, downloaded, print nor accessed. The resources in this category are confidential. The depositor, persons connected to the project and repository administrators may have access to the resource.

Moderately sensitive – refers to resources that are to be viewed only, not to be downloaded and print. Retrievers interested in accessing the resource need to fill ‘Data Retrieval Form’ to justify the need for the resource. Data Retrieval Form to be assessed and approved by the Principal Investigator and co-PIs.
Low sensitive – refers to resources that are to be shared openly. Retrievers will be able to view, download, print and use.
indicates that the Item labeled with this Rights Statement is in copyright.
indicates that the Item labeled with this Rights Statement has been identified as an ‘Orphan Work’ under the terms of the EU Orphan Works Directive.

label.name_singular: In Copyright - Rights-holder(s) Unlocatable or Unidentifiable (InC-RUU)
label.name_plural: In Copyright - Rights-holder(s) Unlocatable or Unidentifiable (InC-RUU)
label.description: indicates that the Item labeled with this Rights Statement has been identified as in copyright, but whose rights-holder(s) either cannot be identified or cannot be located.
indicates that the Item labeled with this Rights Statement is in copyright but that educational use is allowed without the need to obtain additional permission.
indicates that the Item labeled with this Rights Statement is in copyright but that non-commercial use is allowed without the need to obtain additional permission.
indicates that the underlying Work is in the Public Domain, but the organization that has published the Item is contractually required to allow only non-commercial use by third parties.
indicates that the underlying Work is in the Public Domain, but the organization that has published the Item is contractually required to restrict certain forms of use by third parties.

label.name_singular: No Copyright - Other Known Legal Restrictions (NoC-OKLR)
label.name_plural: No Copyright - Other Known Legal Restrictions (NoC-OKLR)
label.description: indicates that the underlying Work is in the Public Domain, but that laws other than copyright impose restrictions on the use of the Item by third parties.

indicates that the underlying Work is in the Public Domain under the laws of the United States, but that a determination was not made as to its copyright status under the copyright laws of other countries.
indicates that the organization that has published the Item believes that no copyright or related rights are known to exist, but that a conclusive determination could not be made.
indicates that the organization that has published the Item has not evaluated the copyright and related rights status of the Item.
indicates that the organization that has made the Item available has reviewed the copyright and related rights status of the Item, but was unable to determine the copyright status of the Item.
The VIAF® (Virtual International Authority File) combines multiple name authority files into a single OCLC-hosted name authority service.

Wikidata is a collaboratively edited multilingual knowledge graph hosted by the Wikimedia Foundation. It is a common source of open data that Wikimedia projects such as Wikipedia, and anyone else, can use under the CC0 public domain license. Wikidata is a wiki powered by the software MediaWiki, including its extension for semi-structured data, the Wikibase.
People and Partner list on Imagining Futures website.

ORCID provides a persistent digital identifier (an ORCID iD) that you own and control, and that distinguishes you from every other researcher. You can connect your iD with your professional information — affiliations, grants, publications, peer review, and more. You can use your iD to share your information with other systems, ensuring you get recognition for all your contributions, saving you time and hassle, and reducing the risk of errors.
